Enhanced catalytic performance for gas phase epoxidation of propylene with H2 and O2 by multiple pretreated Au/TS-1 catalysts Chenyang Zhao Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a b Yujia Liu Investigation Formal analysis Data curation a b Yupeng Tian Formal analysis Data curation b Yahui Li Formal analysis a b Junjie Feng Formal analysis a b Wei Xu Supervision Project administration Investigation a b ⁎ Ning Shi Investigation Formal analysis b Zhe Yang Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition a b ⁎ Bing Sun a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Chemical Safety, 339th Songling Road, Qingdao 266071, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Safety 339th Songling Road Qingdao 266071 China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Safety, 339th Songling Road, Qingdao, 266071, China b SINOPEC Research Institute of Safety Engineering Co., Ltd., 339th Songling Road, Qingdao 266071, China SINOPEC Research Institute of Safety Engineering Co., Ltd. 339th Songling Road Qingdao 266071 China SINOPEC Research Institute of Safety Engineering Co., Ltd., 339th Songling Road, Qingdao, 266071, China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: State Key Laboratory of Chemical Safety, 339th Songling Road, Qingdao 266071, China. State Key Laboratory of Chemical Safety 339th Songling Road Qingdao 266071 China Direct epoxidation of propylene (C3H6) with hydrogen (H2) and oxygen (O2) over Au/TS-1 catalyst was promising way for the synthesis of propylene oxide (PO). However, high selectivity of PO (>95 %) and conversion of C3H6 (>5 %) cannot be achieved at the same time. The industrialization process was severely restricted. In this paper, Au/TS-1 catalysts were synthesized by deposition precipitation method with alkali metal promoter. And alkaline gases and silane coupling post-treatment were performed to promote the catalytic activity. The prepared samples exhibited a much better C3H6 conversion (6.5 %) and PO selectivity (95.1 %) compared with general catalyst using normal synthetic technology. Cs2CO3 was beneficial to increasing Au nanoparticles uptake efficiency. Both NH3 and triethoxyvinylsilane post-treatment were good for smaller and more uniform loading of Au nanoparticles. The decreasing in surface hydroxyl density effectively alleviated the occurrence of PO ring opening isomerization. The increased hydrophobicity of TS-1 surface was conducive to the rapid desorption of generated PO and significantly increased PO selectivity. Multiple pretreatment was also favorable for extending the lifetime of Au/TS-1 catalyst. Graphical Abstract Combination of alkali metal promoters, alkaline gases and silane coupling pretreatment, excellent catalytic performance of Au/TS-1 was obtained. CC3H6, SPO, EH2 and RPO were almost constant after 100 h stability test. Keywords Gas phase epoxidation Au/TS-1 Alkali metal promoter Alkaline gases pretreatment Silane coupling post-treatment Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction As an important bulk chemical propylene oxide (PO) is widely used in polyetheropolyol, polyurethane synthesizing and further applied in chemical industry, cosmetics and medicine field [1]. Normally, PO was produced by the chlorohydrin, organic hydroperoxide and the hydrogene peroxide propylene oxide (HPPO) process. Because of environment pollution, instrument corrosion, mismatching of co-products and poor stability of H2O2. These routes could not meet the safe, green and waste-less needs of chemical production [2]. Gas phase epoxidation of propylene (C3H6) with H2 and O2 to produce PO showed advantages of easy operation, environmental protection and satisfied cost-efficiency. Which has long been considered as a dream reaction [3]. It is widely accepted that Ti-containing zeolites (such as TS-1, TS-2 and Ti-MCM-48) supported Au cluster could catalyze propylene to PO with the help of H2 and O2 [4–9]. Where Au could active H2 and O2 to generate H2O2. H2O2 was converted in-situ in the epoxidation of C3H6 adsorbed on the framework Ti4+ of Ti-zeolites. Therefore, it is necessary to balance the distribution of the Au nanoparticles and Ti4+ for better PO selectivity (SPO) and C3H6 conversion (CC3H6)[10]. In the past decades, an ever-expanding effort of Au loaded catalyst has been explored, Au/TS-1 play a synergistic catalytic role, which showed good catalytic performance in the gas phase epoxidation of propylene with H2 and O2 [3,11–14]. Nevertheless, the industrialization of gas-phase epoxidation was severely restricted by catalytic materials. For Au/TS-1 system, high CC3H6 (>5 %) and better SPO (>95 %) cannot be achieved at the same time. [15,16]. For solving the above problem, Au/TS-1 catalyst has been optimized to further improve its catalytic performance from modification strategies of TS-1 synthesis to Au deposition method [5,17–21]. A series of comparative studies showed that stable and uniformly distributed Au nano-particles, especially those nearing framework Ti4+ were favorable for better SPO [22,23]. Whereas, highly dispersed Au clusters was not easy to be prepared by normal deposition-precipitation method. Owing to the inter-metallic interaction, researchers found that alkali metal such as Cs or Ba is proposed to help stabilize Au particle and restrain the isomerization of PO [20,24–26]. The distribution of Au nanoparticles is also affected by the pre-treatment conditions during the synthesis process. Few reports have discussed the aforementioned impacts, except that Ren et al. had mentioned that owing to the formation of hydrophobic surface, H2-C3H6 pretreated Au/TS-1 exhibited much better catalytic performance [27]. Stangland et al. demonstrated that Au/TS-1 had better catalytic performance when drying under vacuum at room temperature [28]. Although predecessors have done a lot of work, the synthesis of Au/TS-1 catalysts in different pre-treatment scenarios was quite complicated and the mechanisms of different feed treat were still remained unclear. In this paper, we focus on the effects of both alkali metal promoters and different types of pretreatment for Au/TS-1. Generally, distribution of acidic sites on the catalysts and the characterization of hydrophobicity have been carefully investigated. It is found that acidic sites of Au/TS-1 catalysts induced by TiOx or extra-framework of Ti species have been diminished by alkaline gas (NH3) and silanization pretreatment. With the increase the hydrophobicity by reducing the hydroxyl density on the surface of TS-1, PO was easily desorbed and effectively alleviated the occurrence of ring opening isomerization. At the same time, lower density of hydroxyl groups could slow down the possibility of Au nanoparticles flowing on the surface of TS-1 at high temperatures, which will be leading to Ostwald ripening. Consequently, the selectivity of propylene oxide in gas phase epoxidation has been greatly enhanced. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of TS-1 zeolite Traditional hydrothermal method was carried out for TS-1 zeolites synthesizing. In details, 0.51 g tetrabutyl titanate (> 99.9 %, Aladdin) was added to 62.4 g tetraethyl orthosilicate (> 99.9 %, Aladdin). Then 48.8 g tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (25 wt%, Aladdin) and 44.4 g deionized water were mixed with the above mentioned solutions with a stirring rate at 300 r/min for 2 h at 30 ℃. Next, the mixture was heated up to 80 ℃ for another 6 h with a stirring rate at 500 r/min. Then crystallized at 170 ℃ for at least 2 days to producing TS-1 crystals. The TS-1 was washed by distilled water to pH=7. Finally, after going through drying at 100 ℃ for 4 h and calcining at 550 ℃ for 6 h the sample was obtained. 2.2 Au nanoparticle deposition Au nanoparticles were loaded by the deposition precipitation. Firstly, 0.5 g HAuCl4·3 H2O (> 99.9 %, Aladdin) was mixed with 300 ml of deionized water at 30 ℃ with a stirring rate at 300 r/min (solution A). Secondly, 3.0 g TS-1 zeolite was added into solution A and stirring rate increased to 600 r/min for at least 30 min (slurry A). Thirdly, slurry A was then adjusted to pH = 6.6 ∼ 7.0 by adding 0.05 mol L−1 NaOH aqueous solution and further aged for at least 6 h (slurry B). Then 0.01 mol L−1 Cs2CO3, K2CO3 and Na2CO3 aqueous solutions were added to slurry B for another aging 6 h. The pH value was adjusted to 7.4–7.8 (slurry C). Afterward, slurry C was centrifuged with distilled water until the pH value of supernatant near 7.0. Finally, products on the bottom were dried at 25 ℃ and 2 kPa overnight. For comparison, Au/TS-1 catalyst without Cs2CO3, K2CO3 and Na2CO3 treated was also prepared. 2.3 Catalyst pretreatment Au/TS-1 samples were treated with different feed gases before catalytic testing. The pretreatment gases included 1 % NH3, 1 % triethoxyvinylsilane and 98 % N2. For comparison, 1 % NH3+99 % N2, 1 % triethoxyvinylsilane+99 % N2 and pure N2 were also used to treat Au/ TS-1 before catalytic testing. For details, 0.6 g of fresh sample was placed in the middle of a tubular fixed-bed reactor (i.d.=4.6 mm, o.d.=6.6 mm). Both ends of the tube were filled with quartz sand and quartz wool in a sandwich-like packing mode. Then, samples were heated from ambient temperature to 200 ℃ in hydrogen (ramping rate: 1 ℃ min−1) for 4 h. Finally, sweep gas was changed to N2 (99.999 %) for another 60 min treat before C3H6 epoxidation. 2.4 Characterizations The Au/TS-1 samples dispersed in ethanol solution were dried for morphological analyses with FEI Quanta 200 F scanning electron microscope and JEOL JEM-2100 F scanning transmission electron microscopy. The crystal structures of TS-1 zeolites were performed by Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffraction measurements. UltraViolet–visible spectroscopy was carried out for identifying Ti coordination state in Agilent Cary 5000 UV-Vis-NIR spectrophotometer. IR spectroscopy analysis was performed by the Bruker INVENIO R total reflectance infrared spectrometer. The content of Au, O and Ti element was determined by Agilent 5100 inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy data were collected by ESCALab250 Thermo Fisher electron spectrometer. Thermal gravimetric analysis (PerkinElmer TGA Pyris 1) was carried out from 25 ℃ to 800 ℃ with a heating rate of 10 ℃ min−1 in a flow of air. N2 physisorption was performed on a Micromeritics ASAP-2010 instrument at −196 ℃. The NH3-TPD-MS test was performed by homemade chemical adsorption instrument. The 29Si MAS NMR spectra were performed on nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer (Varian VNMRS 400WB) at a frequency of 79.43 MHz using one pulse method, a spinning rate of 3 kHz, a recycling delay of 60 s, and (CH3)3Si(CH2)3SO3Na as a chemical shift reference. 2.5 Catalytic testing The direct propylene epoxidation was carried out in a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor at 180 ℃ and 0.1 MPa. 0.3 g Au/TS-1 catalyst mixed with 1.5–2.5 g quartz sand (50–70 mesh size) were placed in the above reactor with a feed flow of 50 ml min−1 (H2: O2: C3H6: N2 = 10: 10: 10: 70 in vol%). The reactants and products were analyzed by on-line GC (Agilent 7890B) equipped with HP-AL\S, PoraBOUND U, HayeSep Q and Molsieve 5 A column. For the stability test, CC3H6, SPO, H2 efficiency (EH2), PO formation rate (RPO) and carbon balance (Cb) of samples were tested every 30 min. Catalytic performance was calculated by normalization methods defined as follows: (1) CC3H6 = mols of (C3 species except propylene +2/3 C2 species + CO2/3 + CO/3) / mols of feed propylene × 100% (2) SPO = mols of PO / mols of (C3 species except propylene +2/3 C2 species + CO2/3 + CO/3) × 100% (3) EH2 = mols of PO / mols of H2 converted × 100% (4) RPO = mols of PO / mCat × 58.08 (5) Cb = (3 × C3 species + 2 × C2 species + CO2 + CO) / (3 × feed C3H6) 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Fundamental property and characterization of Au/TS-1 Table 1 listed fundamental property of Au/TS-1 samples, from different precipitation agent, final pH by deposition precipitation method to multiple pretreatments. Au loading on the surface and whole Au/TS-1 catalysts were detected by XPS and ICP-OES respectively. Results of ICP-OES showed that the content of Au species in Cat-1 is less than 0.05 wt%. But Au takes over 0.15 wt% on the Cat-4. Cat-2 and Cat-3 also exhibited better Au loading efficiency. Therefore, it can be inferred that the addition of alkali metal carbonate additives helps to increase the loading amount of Au on TS-1. Based on the data in the last two columns of the Table 1, both alkaline gas and silane coupling pretreatments of Au/TS-1 will promote the surface segregation of Au nano-particles. The surface loading of Au in Cat-1 was similar with whole Au loading. However, the ratio of surface to whole of Cat-5 and Cat-6 was nearly doubled. Not to mention the Cat-9 and Cat-10, these two samples were both posts treated by NH3 and SBA. The relevant conclusions could also be obtained from the comparison of Cat-4 and Cat-7, Cat-8, Cat-10. Fundamental pore structural property of Au/TS-1 samples was exhibited in Table S1, the changing in surface area, pore size and volume distribution indicating that micropores blocking happened to a certain extent after Au loading. For further excluding influence from other factors and verifying the positive effect of multiple pretreatment methods on improving catalyst performance, characterization was employed to confirm that the synthesized Au/TS-1 samples had the same MFI structure, titanium framework and similar tetrahedrally coordinated Ti4+ species. Fig. 1 showed IR spectra of samples with different pretreatment. In the range of 400 cm−1∼1800 cm−1, the IR spectrum profiles of Cat-1, Cat-4, Cat-5 and Cat-6 were almost the same. The weak band around 978 cm−1 could be attributed to the stretching vibration of the Si-O bond perturbed by the presence of Ti atom in zeolite framework [29–32]. Peaks around 800 cm−1, 1090 cm−1 and 1230 cm−1 were belonged to the asymmetrical and symmetric stretching vibration of SiO4. Band approximately at 550 cm−1 could be identified as five-membered ring [33,34]. The XRD patterns ( Fig. 2) showed that Cat-1, Cat-4, Cat-5 and Cat-6 were fully crystalline and overlapped with major diffraction peaks (2θ) at 23.2°, 24.0° and 24.5°, corresponding to the cross-channels in the double ten-membered ring [10,29–31]. The single diffraction peak at 24.5° was believed to arise from the presence of Ti in the framework and indicated the formation of orthorhombic symmetry [27,29,30,33,35–37]. XRD patterns of Cat-2, Cat-3 and Cat-7 to Cat-10 were provided in Figure S3 for further demonstrating that all of the samples were successfully synthesized including the presence of Au nanoparticles. As shown in Fig. 3, all samples exhibited a strong adsorption peak around 210 nm, indicating that a distinguishing characteristic of tetrahedrally coordinated Ti4+ species presented in the framework [29,38,39]. Non-framework TiO2 absent in Cat-1, Cat-4, Cat-5 and Cat-6, because no peak was observed in the region of 250 nm to 350 nm [40,41]. Fig. 4 illustrated gas phase epoxidation of propylene test over different samples (Cat-1 to Cat-10). All data were collected after reaction happened for 15 h. It could be intuitively perceived that under the combined action of Cs2CO3 promoters, NH3 and triethoxyvinylsilane pretreatment, PO selectivity and propylene conversion rate dramatically increased from 86.2 %, 4.4 % (Cat-1) to 95.1 %, 6.5 % (Cat-10) respectively. The major function of alkali metal promoters was to improve the conversion rate of propylene. Based on the results in Table 1, it could be concluded that the addition of Cs effectively increased the loading amount of Au nanoparticles, thereby increasing the catalytic active sites. Ultimately, the result reflected on the catalyst was a remarkable increase in propylene conversion rate. Details could be got when comparing the result between Cat-1 and Cat-4. In Fig. 4, SPO changed from 86.2 % (Cat-1) to 92.7 % (Cat-5) when treated with NH3 and converted from 86.2 % (Cat-1) to 92.4 % (Cat-6) when treated with triethoxyvinylsilane before reaction. Actions of alkaline gases and silane coupling pretreatment could be attributed to improving the surface hydrophobicity and reducing the acidic catalytic sites of catalyst. With the effect of the two aspects, generated PO could rapidly desorb from Au/TS-1 and reduce the residence time of PO on catalyst. Due to the weakening of acidic catalytic sites that cause side reactions such as PO ring opening isomerization and oligomerization, the possibility of catalyst carbon deactivation was reduced and SPO was increased as well. 3.2 Effect of alkali metal promoters Fig. 5 showed HRTEM images and particle size distribution of Au/TS-1 from Cat-1 to Cat-10. The table on the bottom right corner of this picture exhibited the statistics of Au nanoparticle size and numbers. The Au particle size was given as an average of at least 500 random manually measured from the HRTEM image. Au nano-particle numbers counted on per 0.01 square micrometers. The Au/TS-1 catalyst prepared by normal deposition precipitation method had a low loading amount and uneven distribution of Au nanoparticles (Cat-1). Due to a strong interaction between Cs and Au, the precipitation agent Cs2CO3 caused a four to five times increase in Au nanoparticle uptake efficiency (Cat-4). Results consistent with what W.-S. Lee et al. had reported [24]. It is generally acknowledged that higher Au loading was propitious to enhance the density of active species and hence increasing reaction rate [20]. This phenomenon also directly explained in Fig. 4. With the addition of Cs2CO3 promoters, the density of “Au-Ti” active centers increased, and propylene conversion was significantly improved from 4.4 % (Cat-1) to 5.8 % (Cat-6). And RPO also increased from 98.8 gPO kgCat −1 h−1 (Cat-1) to 135.8 gPO kgCat −1 h−1 (Cat-6). With the help of alkaline gases and silane coupling pretreatment, the surface hydroxyl of TS-1 was converted into oxygen vacancies, which was more conducive to the loading of Au(OH)x nanoparticles. Therefore, the size control and uniform dispersion of gold nanoparticles were guaranteed (Cat-5, Cat-6). In order to further exhibiting the changes of the catalyst micro-structure after alkaline gases and silane coupling pretreatment, the oxygen vacancies in samples are tested by EPR (Figure S4). And the deviation of the magnetic field indicates a density change between surface hydroxyl species and oxygen vacancies of the catalyst. When combined the addition of Cs2CO3 promoters, NH3 and triethoxyvinylsilane pretreatment, both Au nanoparticle dispersity and uptake efficiency had reached an optimal level for catalyzing propylene epoxidation (Cat-10). And unexpected improvement in the catalytic performance of Au/TS-1 was obtained (Fig. 4, Cat-10). 3.3 Effect of alkaline gases pretreatment Even though alkaline gas and silane coupling pretreatments of Au/TS-1 had little significant effect on the increase of Au load capacity, the particle size was well controlled. As exhibited in Fig. 5, owing to the stabilizing effect between NH3, SBA and Au, the average size of Au nanoparticles decreased from 4.5 nm (Cat-1) to 3.1 nm (Cat-5), 3.2 nm (Cat-6) and 2.6 nm (Cat-9). Similar results also could be obtained when compared Cat-4 (3.3 nm), Cat-7 (2.9 nm), Cat-8 (2.8 nm) and Cat-10 (3.0 nm). Generally, the surface acidity of Au/TS-1 played a crucial role in direct epoxidation of propylene. Minor acidic sites were favorable for stabilizing H2O2 catalyzed by Au cluster. But excessive acidic species were bad for propylene epoxidation [7,42–44]. As previously discussed, unnecessary acidic species would trigger the isomerization or/and oligomerization of PO, consequently resulting in the deactivation of catalyst. Detailed information of different acidity on Au/TS-1 samples provided by the intensity of ammonia mass signal in NH3-TPD-MS. The strong NH3 desorption peak at 184 ℃ (Cat-1) could be ascribed to the acidic species of TiOx or extra-framework of Ti [44]. Peaks of the similar intensity on Cat-4 was found at 180 ℃. This implied that the addition of Cs additives did not make big difference on the distribution of acidic sites and related chemical environment around Au/TS-1 catalyst. However, under the influence of NH3 and triethoxyvinylsilane, the desorption peaks of ammonia on Cat-5, Cat-6 shifted to 170 and 162 ℃ respectively. Since NH3could partially react with extra-framework Ti or TiOx, and change the distribution of acidic species in Au/TS-1. Samples treated by alkaline gases (Cat-5, Cat-9 and Cat-10) exhibited much weak peak intensity. Furthermore, numbers of hydroxyl groups gradually reduced with the introducing silane coupling to Au/TS-1 sample (Cat-6). Due to the decrease in the number of hydroxyl groups, the adsorption and desorption of NH3 on the surface of Au/TS-1 also changed. The shift in peak position towards lower temperature region was specifically displayed in Fig. 6. As a result, with the multiple pretreatments of Cs, NH3 and triethoxyvinylsilane, Cat-10 showed the weakest acidity. 3.4 Effect of silane coupling pretreatment Due to the strong interaction between silane coupling and surface hydroxyl, the number of hydroxyl groups on samples could greatly reduce when treated with triethoxyvinylsilane. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) and 29Si MAS NMR spectra were performed for further explanation of the changing on surface chemical environment and hydrophobicity. FTIR spectra in hydroxyl stretching vibration regions of Cat-1, Cat-4, Cat-5 and Cat-6 were shown in Fig. 7. Two peaks around 3520 cm−1 and 3735 cm−1 were represented silanol groups under different chemical atmosphere. The successful removal of both terminal silanol and silanol nests groups after triethoxyvinylsilane pretreatment on Au/TS-1 (Cat-6) was confirmed by the disappearance of the broad absorbance IR signal around 3520 cm−1 and the obvious weakening of the sharp peak around 3735 cm−1. Because the addition of Cs could effectively increase the loading amount of Au, partial silanol groups were occupied by abundant Au nanoparticles. Cat-4 also exhibited a better control of excessive silanol groups. For Cat-5, NH3 could react with acidic species. The interaction between extra-framework Ti species and ammonia would change the amount of acidity. Meanwhile, A hydrogen bonding structure will be formed between NH3 and silanol groups. This also partially changed the distribution of hydroxyl groups in Au/TS-1. Therefore, two peaks around 3520 cm−1 and 3735 cm−1 were correspondingly weakened. As shown in Fig. 8, 29Si MAS NMR spectroscopy could provide a direct proof on the coordination states of Si species in Au/TS-1 samples. All samples gave main resonance signals at −113 ppm and −103 ppm, corresponding to typical Si(OSi)4 (Q4) and Si(OSi)3OH (Q3) species in tetrahedral coordination. Owing to the addition of alkali metal promoters, alkaline gas and silane coupling pretreatments, Si(OSi)3OH species decreased a lot. As a result, the ratio between Q4 and Q3 signals was increased from 5.126 (Cat-1) to 10.594 (Cat-6). The trend of peak intensity variation exhibited in NMR spectroscopy were coordinate with results revealed in FTIR spectra. In order to further demonstrate intuitively that silane coupling treatment could enhance the hydrophilicity of Au/TS-1 samples, liquid contact angle tests were performed on Cat-1 and Cat-6 (See Figure S2). 3.5 Stability test on Au/TS-1 catalyst Catalytic performance of samples as function of time on stream was exhibited in Fig. 9. Values in this report were measured for three times and the mean values with error bar were presented. CC3H6, SPO, EH2 and RPO on Cat-1, Cat-4, Cat-5 and Cat-10 were compared in same reaction condition (180 ℃, GHSV = 10000 ml gcat −1 h−1, H2: O2: C3H6: N2 = 10: 10: 10: 70 in vol%). As showed in Cat-1, Au/TS-1 synthesized by normal deposition precipitation method without special pretreatment, did not have good performance on catalyzing direct epoxidation on C3H6 with O2 and H2. Cat-1 deactivated after 25 h testing. CC3H6 and SPO decreased with time from initial 4.4 %, 86.2 % to 3.4 %, 78.6 %. Correspondingly, EH2 and RPO decreased from 26.8 %, 98.8 gPO kgCat −1 h−1 to 17.0 %, 68.3 gPO kgCat −1 h−1. For Cat-4, although the addition of Cs could effectively improve the catalytic activity, it might only delay the deactivation of the catalyst and did not fundamentally prolong the catalytic activity. On the contrary, due to the high reaction activity, the generated PO could not be desorbed from the catalyst surface in time, which exacerbated the occurrence of side reactions such as ring opening isomerization and oligomerization, ultimately leading to carbon deposition and pore blockage, resulting in catalyst deactivation. As displayed in Fig. 9, CC3H6 and SPO of Cat-4 decreased from 5.8 %, 89.8 % to 4.5 %, 79.6 %. Accordingly, EH2 and RPO decreased from 33.7 %, 135.8 gPO kgCat −1 h−1 to 19.6 %, 92.0 gPO kgCat −1 h−1. The changing trend of Cat-4 catalytic performance was similar with Cat-1. Deactivation also happened after 20–30 h testing. Considering to the catalytic performance of Cat-5, alkaline gas post-treatment, represented by NH3, could effectively reduce acidic catalytic sites. Excessive acidity could lead to PO ring opening isomerization on the catalyst surface. With the help of alkaline gas pretreatment, the occurrence of side reactions was much reduced, and SPO was much improved when compared with Cat-1. Also, the deactivation of the catalyst due to carbon deposition and pore blockage could be delayed. CC3H6 and SPO decreased slowly with time from initial 5.4 %, 92.7 % to 5.1 %, 91.8 %. Correspondingly, EH2 and RPO changed from 30.5 %, 128.9 gPO kgCat −1 h−1 to 27.7 %, 120.3 gPO kgCat −1 h−1. Cat-6 exhibited similar changing trends on catalytic performance to Cat-5 and details were showed in Figure S1. Silane coupling post-treatment, represented by triethoxyvinylsilane, could improve the surface hydrophobicity of the catalyst, promote the rapid desorption of generated PO, and reduce the residence time of PO on the catalyst surface. Thus, inhibiting the occurrence of side reactions such as PO ring opening isomerization or oligomerization, and improving SPO. Therefore, AuTS-1 deactivation caused by carbon deposition and pore blockage could also be suppressed. When combined the addition of alkali metal promoters, alkaline gases and silane coupling pretreatment together, both Au nanoparticle dispersity and uptake efficiency had become more suitable for this catalytic system. And excessive acidic species was eliminated by NH3, hydrophobic surface of Au/TS-1 was favorable for C3H6 adsorption and PO desorption. After multiple post-treatment of Au/TS-1 (Cat-10), unexpected catalytic performance was obtained. Initial CC3H6, SPO, EH2 and RPO was 6.5 %, 95.1 %, 49.5 % and 160.3 gPO kgCat −1 h−1. All the factors were kept at a high level after 100 h stability test. TG analysis of Au/TS-1 samples after 100 h testing was then carried out in the temperature range of 30–800 ℃. As showed in Fig. 10, the percentage of total coke weight in Cat-1 (8.16 wt%) was 8 times that in Cat-10 (1.02 wt%), indicating that catalyst after multiple pretreatment was beneficial for the inhibition of the coke formation. Samples after the addition of Cs2CO3 promoter (Cat-4) and NH3 post-treatment (Cat-5), could also suppress the deactivation caused by carbon deposition and pore blockage to a certain degree. On the other hand, It should be noted that the 1.02 wt% weight loss in Cat-10 included the residual template. The characterizations of pore structural property and crystalline structure of the recycled samples were presented in Table S2 and Figure S5 correspondingly. 4 Conclusion Gas phase epoxidation of propylene with H2 and O2 has attracted great attention due to its efficient and environmental merit. This report focused on multiple pretreatment for Au/TS-1. Effect of alkali metal promoters, alkaline gases and silane coupling pretreatments had been carefully investigated. Cs2CO3 promoter was beneficial to increasing Au nanoparticles uptake efficiency. Both NH3 and triethoxyvinylsilane post-treatment were good for smaller and more uniform loading of Au nanoparticles. The decreasing in surface hydroxyl density effectively alleviated the occurrence of PO ring opening isomerization. At the same time, silane coupling treatment increased the hydrophobicity of TS-1 surface, which was conducive to the rapid desorption of generated PO and significantly increases SPO. When combined the addition of alkali metal promoters, alkaline gases and silane coupling pretreatment, excellent catalytic performance of Au/TS-1 was obtained. CC3H6, SPO, EH2 and RPO were almost constant after 100 h stability test. This also proved that multiple pretreatment strategy used in this report was effective in improving the catalytic performance of Au/TS-1 and provides a new idea for the theoretical research of heterogeneous synergistic catalysis by exploring the mechanism of adsorption, desorption, dispersion, migration and transformation mechanism of complex catalytic system. coredata.dc:description: Direct epoxidation of propylene (C3H6) with hydrogen (H2) and oxygen (O2) over Au/TS-1 catalyst was promising way for the synthesis of propylene oxide (PO). However, high selectivity of PO (>95 %) and conversion of C3H6 (>5 %) cannot be achieved at the same time. The industrialization process was severely restricted. In this paper, Au/TS-1 catalysts were synthesized by deposition precipitation method with alkali metal promoter. And alkaline gases and silane coupling post-treatment were performed to promote the catalytic activity. The prepared samples exhibited a much better C3H6 conversion (6.5 %) and PO selectivity (95.1 %) compared with general catalyst using normal synthetic technology. Cs2CO3 was beneficial to increasing Au nanoparticles uptake efficiency. Both NH3 and triethoxyvinylsilane post-treatment were good for smaller and more uniform loading of Au nanoparticles. The decreasing in surface hydroxyl density effectively alleviated the occurrence of PO ring opening isomerization. The increased hydrophobicity of TS-1 surface was conducive to the rapid desorption of generated PO and significantly increased PO selectivity. Multiple pretreatment was also favorable for extending the lifetime of Au/TS-1 catalyst.
